attachments.22862169067a6a2dd95277af854c9f66:
Task Description: ## Description This adds support for custom trust policy conditions to the `iam-github-oidc-role` module. ## Motivation and Context The GitHub documentation on [security hardening with OpenID connect] (https://docs.github.com/en/actions/security-for-github-actions/security-hardening-your-deployments/about-security-hardening-with-openid-connect) specifies that: > You can define granular OIDC policies by using additional OIDC token claims, such as repository_id and repository_visibility. See [Understanding the OIDC token](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/security-for-github-actions/security-hardening-your-deployments/about-security-hardening-with-openid-connect#understanding-the-oidc-token). However, this module currently only supports validation of `iss`, `aud` and `sub`. I have a use case where I also want to validate `actor` and `workflow` but without this change, the module doesn't support that. ## Breaking Changes I do not believe this breaks any backwards compatibility. The added variable defaults to an empty array of entries, much like in the `iam-assumable-role-with-oidc` modules and the dynamic configuration will not add anything if no values are provided. ## How Has This Been Tested? - [x] I have updated at least one of the `examples/*` to demonstrate and validate my change(s) - [x] I have tested and validated these changes using one or more of the provided `examples/*` projects > caveat: I don't have a space where I can deploy the examples but I have successfully tested the updated module against corporate accounts where I am employed. - [x] I have executed `pre-commit run -a` on my pull request > ~~caveat: terraform-docs also affected 8 other REAMDE files (for modules I have not touched in this PR) but I have not checked those changes in. I can if you'd like. All other pre-commmit checks passed.~~ this was due to using an outdated version of TF (1.5.5, I updated to 1.10.5 and it resolved this) --- Choice A: examples/iam-github-oidc/main.tf @@ -46,6 +46,24 @@ module "iam_github_oidc_role" { "terraform-aws-modules/terraform-aws-iam:ref:refs/heads/master", ] + # As per the Github documentation for security hardening with OpenID Connect + # (https://docs.github.com/en/actions/security-for-github-actions/security-hardening-your-deployments/about-security-hardening-with-openid-connect) + # This document makes many references to the fact that you can leverage any of the available + # OIDC claims to when configuring the cloud providers trust relation. For example in + # https://docs.github.com/en/actions/security-for-github-actions/security-hardening-your-deployments/about-security-hardening-with-openid-connect#customizing-the-token-claims + # it is specified that granular OIDC policies can be defined using additional OIDC token claims. + # In this example, we ensure that the OIDC token GitHub uses to assume the AWS IAM role has the correct + # `actor` scope. + additional_trust_policy_conditions = [ + { + test = "StringEquals" + variable = "${module.iam_github_oidc_provider.url}:actor" + # This should be the list of GitHub usernames for which you want to restrict + # access to the role. + values = ["username"] + } + ] + policies = { additional = aws_iam_policy.additional.arn S3ReadOnly = "arn:aws:iam::aws:policy/AmazonS3ReadOnlyAccess" --- modules/iam-github-oidc-role/README.md @@ -82,6 +82,7 @@ No modules. | Name | Description | Type | Default | Required | |------|-------------|------|---------|:--------:| +| [additional\_trust\_policy\_conditions](#input\_additional\_trust\_policy\_conditions) | Additional conditions for the constraint to apply to the trust policy | 
list(object({
    test     = string
    variable = string
    values   = list(string)
  }))
| `[]` | no | | [audience](#input\_audience) | Audience to use for OIDC role. Defaults to `sts.amazonaws.com` for use with the [official AWS GitHub action](https://github.com/aws-actions/configure-aws-credentials) | `string` | `"sts.amazonaws.com"` | no | | [create](#input\_create) | Controls if resources should be created (affects all resources) | `bool` | `true` | no | | [description](#input\_description) | IAM Role description | `string` | `null` | no | --- modules/iam-github-oidc-role/main.tf @@ -47,6 +47,16 @@ data "aws_iam_policy_document" "this" { # Strip `repo:` to normalize for cases where users may prepend it values = [for subject in var.subjects : "repo:${trimprefix... attachments.bf96a49de747850c214bebace60b9a29:
**Comparing Terraform patches**

I'm carefully comparing options A and C for differences. They both have the same example sentence referencing the `actor` scope, which is good. It seems both A and C are valid, but B and D contain corruption in their content. I notice A has an added line in the README, and both implement the IAM change correctly. Since they seem comparable, I've randomly chosen A to go with for the best Terraform patch that implements the change safely.**Confirming choice between A and C**

I'm double-checking the details regarding the dynamic "condition" with `for_each = var.additional_trust_policy_conditions`. If the variable is an empty list, no conditions will be added, which is a good edge case to consider. The 'variable' field should be like "${module.iam_github_oidc_provider.url}:actor" but needs to be documented as a string for user input, which is confirmed. The wrappers mapping has a minor ordering change. After all this, I've decided to go with A as the final answer.

Task Description:
## Description
This pull request includes updates to the IAM policy document for external secrets in the `modules/iam-role-for-service-accounts-eks/policies.tf` file. The changes adjust the actions allowed for the secrets manager.

Changes to IAM policy document:

* Added the `secretsmanager:BatchGetSecretValue` action to the list of allowed actions in one statement.
* Removed the `secretsmanager:BatchGetSecretValue` action from another statement to avoid redundancy.

## Motivation and Context

Two weeks ago, the `0.12.1`  version was launched for external-secrets. The new version requires a new permission for the action  `BatchGetSecretValue`.

I opened this PR  https://github.com/terraform-aws-modules/terraform-aws-iam/pull/542  with the suggested changes from the external-secrets repo, and the proposed policy was not working as expected. After reviewing it and reporting it to external-secrets, they finally modified the documentation with a working policy (https://github.com/external-secrets/external-secrets/pull/4275).

The new policy has been tested and works properly with the latest version.

## Breaking Changes
No breaking changes

## How Has This Been Tested?
- [ ] I have updated at least one of the `examples/*` to demonstrate and validate my change(s)
- [x] I have tested and validated these changes using one or more of the provided `examples/*` projects
<!--- Users should start with an existing example as its written, deploy it, then check their changes against it -->
<!--- This will highlight breaking/disruptive changes. Once you have checked, deploy your changes to verify -->
<!--- Please describe how you tested your changes -->
- [x] I have executed `pre-commit run -a` on my pull request
<!--- Please see https://github.com/antonbabenko/pre-commit-terraform#how-to-install for how to install -->


---

-    actions   = ["secretsmanager:ListSecrets"]
+    actions   = ["secretsmanager:ListSecrets", "secretsmanager:BatchGetSecretValue"]
     resources = ["*"]
   }
 
@@ -557,8 +557,7 @@ data "aws_iam_policy_document" "external_secrets" {
       "secretsmanager:GetResourcePolicy",
       "secretsmanager:GetSecretValue",
       "secretsmanager:DescribeSecret",
-      "secretsmanager:ListSecretVersionIds",
-      "secretsmanager:BatchGetSecretValue",

**Evaluating Terraform patches**

I need to choose the best Terraform patch for safely implementing IAM changes with a documentation-only update for the Mountpoint S3 CSI Driver. I should evaluate patches A, B, C, and D by inspecting their differences. Patch A looks valid since it includes the Mountpoint S3 CSI Driver in the list of optional supported policies. Ill compare how the other patches spell the Node Termination Handler differently, but I need clarity on which one follows the original.**Reviewing patch options**

Let's take a closer look at the differences in Choice A. It adds the Mountpoint S3 CSI Driver link correctly in the README file among other supported policies. That's a good move! However, in Choice B, theres a typo that introduces S3 - [App Mesh Envoy Proxy], which creates a formatting error. Plus, it spells "Node Termination Handler" differently instead of as the "Node AWS Handler." This poor formatting in Choice B makes it not safe to use.**Inspecting patch differences**

In Choice C, things go wrong with weird brackets and line merging that clearly make it a poor option. Then, in Choice D, it closely resembles Choice A, but here the differences lie in naming. D includes "Node Termination Handler" instead of "Node AWS Handler" from A. The structure seems consistent with the original repository link label for the "Node Termination Handler," but I need to verify if that was indeed what the original file had. I'm curious to check the context lines from each patch for clarity.**Choosing the right patch**

I need to select a patch that correctly adds the Mountpoint S3 CSI Driver line to the README while keeping the surrounding content intact. Choice A does insert the mountpoint line but retains "Node AWS Handler," which might be incorrect. Meanwhile, Choice D also adds the mountpoint line but uses "Node Termination Handler." I need to clarify which term is accurate. Looking at the context, it seems more typical for the project to refer to it as "Node Termination Handler." My goal here is to find the patch with the least errors while implementing the requested IAM change safely.**Selecting the best patch**

Both Choices A and D correctly add the mountpoint link line, while B and C have formatting errors that break them. The main difference between A and D lies in their usage of "Node AWS Handler" and "Node Termination Handler." D aligns better with the linked project's common labeling. This implies that it is more consistent with the original README. Since D maintains accuracy and clarity throughout the patch while including all necessary changes, it seems like the best choice. Therefore, I'll go with D.

**Evaluating Terraform patches**

I need to choose the best Terraform patch that implements an IAM change safely, but it seems the content is more about updating CI workflow versions. The developer's instruction is to select one optionA, B, C, or Dfor the IAM change, which isnt clearly shown here. All the choices appear nearly identical, involving version updates and removalsso Ill carefully check each choice for any anomalies or minor differences, including whitespace issues.**Inspecting Choice C for errors**

Looking closely at Choice C, I notice a small mis-indentation in the pre-commit.yml. The indentation for "       - name: Terraform min/max versions" seems off compared to the other optionsmaybe it has an extra space? 

In Choice A, the formatting appears consistent even with the updates to version numbers. Choice B looks exactly the same. When checking Choice C, the line "       - name" doesn't align properly with "         id: minMax." It seems the hyphen alignment might be the issue here, so I need to keep this in mind.**Finalizing the patch selection**

I see that the diff snippet may not show clear differences, but everything appears nearly identical across the choices. Choice D looks the same as A and B. It seems like all the patches remove "powershell," but there's a chance one of the patches also updates the pre-commit configuration in .pre-commit-config.yaml. 

I need to check this in Choice A as well. Perhaps it's a multiple-choice question where only one option is correct. Ill compare every patch carefully, looking closely for any small differences, specifically focusing on the `if` condition in pre-commit.yml.**Examining Choice A for errors**

In reviewing Choice A, I notice the changes in the pre-commit.yml file. The updates for the Terraform min/max versions and the pre-commit action versions seem correct. However, I spot an oddity in the conditional statement: "if: Terraform matrix.directory !=  '.' }}" appears to have a syntax error. It looks like theres a merge error where the ${{ is misplaced. It should read "if: ${{ matrix.directory != '.' }}". Ill need to check this closely, as it might affect the patch's functionality.**Deciding on the best patch**

Im going back to revisit the original description for the conditional statement. Choice B retains the correct syntax, while Choice A has a broken line with the incorrect formatting. Choice C looks fine, and Choice D is identical to B. It appears only Choice A has that invalid syntax, which would indeed break the CI.

Choices B, C, and D all seem equivalent, but I should choose one. I lean towards B since it's often preferred in these scenarios. Now, I'll finalize my response: Ill go with "B" as my answer.

**Evaluating Terraform patches**

I need to choose the best Terraform patch that implements an IAM change safely, but it seems the content is more about updating CI workflow versions. The developer's instruction is to select one optionA, B, C, or Dfor the IAM change, which isnt clearly shown here. All the choices appear nearly identical, involving version updates and removalsso Ill carefully check each choice for any anomalies or minor differences, including whitespace issues.**Inspecting Choice C for errors**

Looking closely at Choice C, I notice a small mis-indentation in the pre-commit.yml. The indentation for "       - name: Terraform min/max versions" seems off compared to the other optionsmaybe it has an extra space? 

In Choice A, the formatting appears consistent even with the updates to version numbers. Choice B looks exactly the same. When checking Choice C, the line "       - name" doesn't align properly with "         id: minMax." It seems the hyphen alignment might be the issue here, so I need to keep this in mind.**Finalizing the patch selection**

I see that the diff snippet may not show clear differences, but everything appears nearly identical across the choices. Choice D looks the same as A and B. It seems like all the patches remove "powershell," but there's a chance one of the patches also updates the pre-commit configuration in .pre-commit-config.yaml. 

I need to check this in Choice A as well. Perhaps it's a multiple-choice question where only one option is correct. Ill compare every patch carefully, looking closely for any small differences, specifically focusing on the `if` condition in pre-commit.yml.**Examining Choice A for errors**

In reviewing Choice A, I notice the changes in the pre-commit.yml file. The updates for the Terraform min/max versions and the pre-commit action versions seem correct. However, I spot an oddity in the conditional statement: "if: Terraform matrix.directory !=  '.' }}" appears to have a syntax error. It looks like theres a merge error where the ${{ is misplaced. It should read "if: ${{ matrix.directory != '.' }}". Ill need to check this closely, as it might affect the patch's functionality.**Deciding on the best patch**

Im going back to revisit the original description for the conditional statement. Choice B retains the correct syntax, while Choice A has a broken line with the incorrect formatting. Choice C looks fine, and Choice D is identical to B. It appears only Choice A has that invalid syntax, which would indeed break the CI.

Choices B, C, and D all seem equivalent, but I should choose one. I lean towards B since it's often preferred in these scenarios. Now, I'll finalize my response: Ill go with "B" as my answer.

Task Description: ## Description Resolves #509 Defaults `enable_mfa_enforcement` to `false` as it should be an opt-in feature. ## Motivation and Context Users migrating from older version (example version 5.3.1) to current version may find that IAM groups users with `attach_iam_self_management_policy` set to `true` suddenly lose access to their consoles, which can cause more harm than good. ## Breaking Changes This change should maintain backward compatibility for users migrating from versions prior to 5.14.3. However, users having versions 5.14.3 and beyond may find that MFA enforcement no longer being enforced by default, requiring `enable_mfa_enforcement` to be explicitly set to `true`. ## How Has This Been Tested? - [ ] I have updated at least one of the `examples/*` to demonstrate and validate my change(s) - [ ] I have tested and validated these changes using one or more of the provided `examples/*` projects - [ ] I have executed `pre-commit run -a` on my pull request --- Choice A: modules/iam-group-with-policies/README.md @@ -44,7 +44,7 @@ No modules. | [create\_group](#input\_create\_group) | Whether to create IAM group | `bool` | `true` | no | | [custom\_group\_policies](#input\_custom\_group\_policies) | List of maps of inline IAM policies to attach to IAM group. Should have `name` and `policy` keys in each element. | `list(map(string))` | `[]` | no | | [custom\_group\_policy\_arns](#input\_custom\_group\_policy\_arns) | List of IAM policies ARNs to attach to IAM group | `list(string)` | `[]` | no | -| [enable\_mfa\_enforcement](#input\_enable\_mfa\_enforcement) | Determines whether permissions are added to the policy which requires the groups IAM users to use MFA | `bool` | `true` | no | +| [enable\_mfa\_enforcement](#input\_enable\_mfa\_enforcement) | Determines whether permissions are added to the policy which requires the groups IAM users to use MFA. Warning: If set to `true`, users without MFA in this group will be denied access to resources, even though permissions are given. | `bool` | `false` | no | | [group\_users](#input\_group\_users) | List of IAM users to have in an IAM group which can assume the role | `list(string)` | `[]` | no | | [iam\_self\_management\_policy\_name\_prefix](#input\_iam\_self\_management\_policy\_name\_prefix) | Name prefix for IAM policy to create with IAM self-management permissions | `string` | `"IAMSelfManagement-"` | no | | [name](#input\_name) | Name of IAM group | `string` | `""` | no | --- modules/iam-group-with-policies/variables.tf @@ -35,9 +35,9 @@ variable "custom_group_policies" { } variable "enable_mfa_enforcement" { - description = "Determines whether permissions are added to the policy which requires the groups IAM users to use MFA" + description = "Determines whether permissions are added to the policy which requires the groups IAM users to use MFA. Warning: If set to `true`, users without MFA in this group will be denied access to resources, even though permissions are given." type = bool - default = true + default = false } variable "attach_iam_self_management_policy" { --- --- Choice B: modules/iam-group-with-policies/README.md @@ -44,7 +44,7 @@ No modules. | [create\_group](#input\_create\_group) | Whether to create IAM group | `bool` | `true` | no | | [custom\_group\_policies](#input\_custom\_group\_policies) | List of maps of inline IAM policies to attach to IAM group. attachments.2de733bcf216631c7c059b4cab88f7d7:
**Analyzing code changes**

I'm exploring a diff where the '-' line indicates what's being removed and the '+' line shows new additions. The removed line in choice B includes backticks around "false," suggesting a previous bug with the description. This patch aims to correct that by replacing it with a warning and setting the default to false. 

But without seeing the original code from the repository, I can only speculate. Choice C shows a README modification that includes the phrase "to If to IAM group," which seems like corrupted text, whereas it should say "to attach to IAM group."**Reviewing code changes**

In choice C, the README incorrectly states "to If to IAM group," which looks like a typo. The variables.tf file matches choice A, where the description is updated, and default is set to false. That doesn't seem ideal!

As for choice D, the README is the same as A, but the variables.tf file is similar with an extra entry showing "attach_iam_self_management_policy." The diff indicates a change in the description for "enable_mfa_enforcement," but it seems like it's cut off, which needs further inspection.**Assessing variable changes**

I see that if set to `true`, users without MFA in this group will lose access to resources, though they may have permissions. The default is switched from `true` to `false`, which changes the implications.

At the end of the variable list, there's a line for "attach_iam_self_management_policy," but it seems like there's an HTML anchor tag stuck in there, which breaks Terraform syntax! So, choice D is certainly broken. In comparison, choice A looks clean without typos. Choice B has its issues, but its final content aligns with A, so it might be okay.**Comparing choices A to D**

I'm comparing choices A, B, C, and D. In choice A, the original removal line updated the description to include a warning about users without MFA being denied access if set to `true`. 

In contrast, choice B fixes a strange string by replacing it with the correct description regarding MFA permissions, but it also seems unclear which is better overall. The question specifies I should respond with a single uppercase letter to indicate the best patch that safely implements the IAM change.**Selecting the best patch**

I need to determine which patch is the best option. After reviewing, I find that choice A is the best because it defaults to false and updates the README to include a warning. It also ensures backwards compatibility, with the README and variables.tf reflecting this change clearly.

Choice B has some questionable modifications, but the final content is the same as A, so it could be acceptable. Meanwhile, choices C and D have issues that make them unsuitable. Therefore, choice A is the safest option, so Ill confidently select "A."

Task Description:
## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->

We are in need of having the enterprise suffix in our github oidc. This change should allow us to use the terraform-aws-iam submodule with ease.

## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
There are github users which use the enterprise path in the github issuer field.
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->

## Breaking Changes
<!-- Does this break backwards compatibility with the current major version? -->
<!-- If so, please provide an explanation why it is necessary. -->

<!--- This will highlight breaking/disruptive changes. Once you have checked, deploy your changes to verify -->

- [x] I have executed `pre-commit run -a` on my pull request
<!--- Please see https://github.com/antonbabenko/pre-commit-terraform#how-to-install for how to install -->

content.reasoning:
**Examining code differences**

It seems that switching to local changes the enterprise suffix. I'm noting differences between patches A, B, C, and D. In patch A, the variable "token.actions.githubusercontent.com:iss" had unintended spaces, which I replaced with "variable = \"${local.provider_url}:iss\"". In choice B, there's an extra open brace at the start of a block, which could cause a syntax error. This newly found "{" appears before "test" and seems misplaced compared to earlier code that uses "condition {".**Analyzing Terraform patches**

So, the original patch used 'condition { \n test = "ForAllValues:StringEquals", and just adding "{" alone would remove the 'condition' keyword, breaking the code. However, patch B shows changes within inner lines, which creates ambiguity. Patches C and D look identical regarding changes and formatting. Now, I need to compare A against C and D, noting that while they all have the same textual replacements, the chosen patch must ensure string interpolation is correctly escaped. Also, it's crucial to quote the condition variable key properly in Terraform HCL.**Clarifying variable properties in HCL**

In the HCL block, I've identified that the condition contains a variable property set as a string. The proposal is to change this variable to include interpolation with local.provider_url. However, my concern is that the variable should be a string literal instead of using interpolation. The condition variable seems to expect "token.actions.githubusercontent.com:aud" for the issuer claim. So, I think the variable should remain "token.actions.githubusercontent.com:iss" as a literal string, but for enterprise issuers, we could allow "${local.provider_url}:iss". Now, I need to review the differences, particularly how the change affects the 'values' array.**Analyzing provider_url and patches**

Im considering the implications if local.provider_url already includes the domain 'token.actions.githubusercontent.com'. It seems they might want to support paths like "https://token.actions.githubusercontent.com" or "https://token.actions.githubusercontent.com/enterprise/<org>". The request for an "enterprise suffix" in GitHub OIDC suggests they need to append an enterprise path to the issuer. The new 'values' line, "https://${local.provider_url}", seems correct if local.provider_url equals "token.actions.githubusercontent.com". However, variations in formatting across patches A, B, C, and D require careful examination, especially the extraneous brace in B and the variable alignment issues in A.**Evaluating patch choices**

In examining patch A, I've noticed that the variable line appears to be missing the equal sign, showing "variable  'token.actions.githubusercontent.com:iss'" instead of "variable = ". This indicates a potential error in the diff representation. Patch B has an extraneous brace that might cause issues, while choices C and D appear identical, reflecting the correct variable assignment with interpolation. I need to ensure that there's no subtlety with quotes around the variable, but both C and D show the variable properly quoted. Since C and D are the same, Ill choose C as the correct answer.

attachments.247a1d0cc9c81f95b90eddefeadb8ea2:
**Examining code differences**

It seems that switching to local changes the enterprise suffix. I'm noting differences between patches A, B, C, and D. In patch A, the variable "token.actions.githubusercontent.com:iss" had unintended spaces, which I replaced with "variable = \"${local.provider_url}:iss\"". In choice B, there's an extra open brace at the start of a block, which could cause a syntax error. This newly found "{" appears before "test" and seems misplaced compared to earlier code that uses "condition {".**Analyzing Terraform patches**

So, the original patch used 'condition { \n test = "ForAllValues:StringEquals", and just adding "{" alone would remove the 'condition' keyword, breaking the code. However, patch B shows changes within inner lines, which creates ambiguity. Patches C and D look identical regarding changes and formatting. Now, I need to compare A against C and D, noting that while they all have the same textual replacements, the chosen patch must ensure string interpolation is correctly escaped. Also, it's crucial to quote the condition variable key properly in Terraform HCL.**Clarifying variable properties in HCL**

In the HCL block, I've identified that the condition contains a variable property set as a string. The proposal is to change this variable to include interpolation with local.provider_url. However, my concern is that the variable should be a string literal instead of using interpolation. The condition variable seems to expect "token.actions.githubusercontent.com:aud" for the issuer claim. So, I think the variable should remain "token.actions.githubusercontent.com:iss" as a literal string, but for enterprise issuers, we could allow "${local.provider_url}:iss". Now, I need to review the differences, particularly how the change affects the 'values' array.**Analyzing provider_url and patches**

Im considering the implications if local.provider_url already includes the domain 'token.actions.githubusercontent.com'. It seems they might want to support paths like "https://token.actions.githubusercontent.com" or "https://token.actions.githubusercontent.com/enterprise/<org>". The request for an "enterprise suffix" in GitHub OIDC suggests they need to append an enterprise path to the issuer. The new 'values' line, "https://${local.provider_url}", seems correct if local.provider_url equals "token.actions.githubusercontent.com". However, variations in formatting across patches A, B, C, and D require careful examination, especially the extraneous brace in B and the variable alignment issues in A.**Evaluating patch choices**

In examining patch A, I've noticed that the variable line appears to be missing the equal sign, showing "variable  'token.actions.githubusercontent.com:iss'" instead of "variable = ". This indicates a potential error in the diff representation. Patch B has an extraneous brace that might cause issues, while choices C and D appear identical, reflecting the correct variable assignment with interpolation. I need to ensure that there's no subtlety with quotes around the variable, but both C and D show the variable properly quoted. Since C and D are the same, Ill choose C as the correct answer.

Task Description:
Update VPC CNI policy to version released on 3/4/24. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/aws-managed-policy/latest/reference/AmazonEKS_CNI_Policy.html

## Description
The VPC CNI policy is missing `ec2:DescribeSubnets ` from the updated policy.

## Motivation and Context
The AWS managed VPC CNI 1.18.0 uses ec2:DescribeSubnets.

## Breaking Changes
Updates VPC CNI policy.
Open issue: https://github.com/terraform-aws-modules/terraform-aws-iam/issues/474

- I have tested with a local project. This is the Terraform plan. It shows `ec2:DescribeSubnets` being added.

        id          = "arn:aws:iam::<redacted>:policy/AmazonEKS_CNI_Policy-20240117193907447200000001"
        name        = "AmazonEKS_CNI_Policy-20240117193907447200000001"
      ~ policy      = jsonencode(
          ~ {
              ~ Statement = [
                  ~ {
                      ~ Action   = [
                            # (3 unchanged elements hidden)
                            "ec2:DescribeTags",
                          + "ec2:DescribeSubnets",
                            "ec2:DescribeNetworkInterfaces",
                            # (6 unchanged elements hidden)
                        ]
                        # (3 unchanged attributes hidden)
                    },
                    {
                        Action   = "ec2:CreateTags"
                        Effect   = "Allow"
                        Resource = "arn:aws:ec2:*:*:network-interface/*"
                        Sid      = "CreateTags"
                    },
                ]
                # (1 unchanged attribute hidden)
            }
        )
        tags        = {}
        # (6 unchanged attributes hidden)
    }
```

But, oh no, Choice C introduces a syntax error with an extra bracket at the top, making it a flawed option. It's interesting to note that even small differences can cause issues. I believe any of the A, B, or D options are good, but definitely avoiding Choice C.**Finalizing patch selection**

I'm tasked with choosing the best patch. It seems I only need to remove one line, which makes options A, B, and D all valid. But, focusing on safety, Ill go with A as its the first one. I have to respond with just a single uppercase letter, so Ill go with "A". Double-checking, the change involves reducing lines from seven to six, which confirms it's a safe modification. Clearly, the answer is "A".

Task Description:
## Description
This allows a user to change their own password when no MFA is present on the account. This is only needed in once situation: when a new users signs in, and is then forced to choose a new password. The MFA isn't set up at that point, and the changing of the password is blocked.

## Motivation and Context
Currently users created with the iam_user and iam_group_with_policies are not able to sign in.
- Resolves #471 

## Breaking Changes
Don't think so

## How Has This Been Tested?
- [ ] I have updated at least one of the `examples/*` to demonstrate and validate my change(s)
- [ ] I have tested and validated these changes using one or more of the provided `examples/*` projects
- [ ] I have executed `pre-commit run -a` on my pull request

I tested this manually using a new account

         "iam:ListVirtualMFADevices",

-        "sts:GetSessionToken"
+        "sts:GetSessionToken",
+        "iam:ChangePassword"
       ]

Task Description: ## Description Add an extra variable so that the assume-roles policy created by iam-group-with-assumable-roles-policy module can be customized with minimal effort: just have an optional suffix that defaults to empty so this PR is fully backwards compatible. Eg ``` module "iam_group_with_assumable_roles_policy_production_admin" { source = "../../modules/iam-group-with-assumable-roles-policy" name = "production-admin" assumable_roles = [module.iam_assumable_roles_in_prod.admin_iam_role_arn] assumable_roles_policy_name_suffix = "-assumable-roles" ... ``` ## Motivation and Context I have been using this module for many months and I really dislike the default name, which is just the group name, because I for one have IAM groups that have a policies named after them since they represenent the group's "main permissions". Eg if I create group `Foo`, I have policy named `Foo` that gives that group it's basic set of permissions (eg read-only permissions), and I want a policy `FooAssumeRoles` that provides the roles that can be assumed by members of that group. ## Breaking Changes None ## How Has This Been Tested? - [x] I have updated at least one of the `examples/*` to demonstrate and validate my change(s) - [x] I have tested and validated these changes using one or more of the provided `examples/*` projects - [x] I have executed `pre-commit run -a` on my pull request I applied using the example, in my own AWS account, on master branch. Then I switched to my branch and re-planned: no changes. Then, I set a non-empty value to `assumable_roles_policy_name_suffix` and the diff was correct: policy would be replaced due to new name and the attachment too. --- Choice A: examples/iam-group-with-assumable-roles-policy/main.tf @@ -107,7 +107,8 @@ module "iam_group_with_assumable_roles_policy_production_readonly" { module "iam_group_with_assumable_roles_policy_production_admin" { source = "../../modules/iam-group-with-assumable-roles-policy" - name = "production-admin" + name = "production-admin" + assumable_roles_policy_name_suffix = "-assumable-roles" assumable_roles = [module.iam_assumable_roles_in_prod.admin_iam_role_arn] --- modules/iam-group-with-assumable-roles-policy/README.md @@ -35,6 +35,7 @@ No modules. | Name | Description | Type | Default | Required | |------|-------------|------|---------|:--------:| | [assumable\_roles](#input\_assumable\_roles) | List of IAM roles ARNs which can be assumed by the group | `list(string)` | `[]` | no | +| [assumable\_roles\_policy\_name\_suffix](#input\_assumable\_roles\_policy\_name\_suffix) | Append this name to the policy name that will be created for assuming the given roles (default: null -- the policy name will be group name) | `string` | `""` | no | | [group\_users](#input\_group\_users) | List of IAM users to have in an IAM group which can assume the | `list(string)` | `[]` | no | | [name](#input\_name) | Name of IAM policy and IAM group | `string` | n/a | yes | | [path](#input\_path) | Path of IAM policy and IAM group | `string` | `"/"` | no | --- modules/iam-group-with-assumable-roles-policy/main.tf @@ -7,7 +7,7 @@ data "aws_iam_policy_document" "assume_role" { } resource "aws_iam_policy" "this" { - attachments.372f776b1de2846af18e4f59404be075: Task Description: ## Description Add an extra variable so that the assume-roles policy created by iam-group-with-assumable-roles-policy module can be customized with minimal effort: just have an optional suffix that defaults to empty so this PR is fully backwards compatible. Eg ``` module "iam_group_with_assumable_roles_policy_production_admin" { source = "../../modules/iam-group-with-assumable-roles-policy" name = "production-admin" assumable_roles = [module.iam_assumable_roles_in_prod.admin_iam_role_arn] assumable_roles_policy_name_suffix = "-assumable-roles" ... ``` ## Motivation and Context I have been using this module for many months and I really dislike the default name, which is just the group name, because I for one have IAM groups that have a policies named after them since they represenent the group's "main permissions". Eg if I create group `Foo`, I have policy named `Foo` that gives that group it's basic set of permissions (eg read-only permissions), and I want a policy `FooAssumeRoles` that provides the roles that can be assumed by members of that group. ## Breaking Changes None ## How Has This Been Tested? - [x] I have updated at least one of the `examples/*` to demonstrate and validate my change(s) - [x] I have tested and validated these changes using one or more of the provided `examples/*` projects - [x] I have executed `pre-commit run -a` on my pull request I applied using the example, in my own AWS account, on master branch. Then I switched to my branch and re-planned: no changes. Then, I set a non-empty value to `assumable_roles_policy_name_suffix` and the diff was correct: policy would be replaced due to new name and the attachment too. --- Choice A: examples/iam-group-with-assumable-roles-policy/main.tf @@ -107,7 +107,8 @@ module "iam_group_with_assumable_roles_policy_production_readonly" { module "iam_group_with_assumable_roles_policy_production_admin" { source = "../../modules/iam-group-with-assumable-roles-policy" - name = var.name + name = "${var.name}${var.assumable_roles_policy_name_suffix}" path = var.path description = "Allows to assume role in another AWS account" policy = data.aws_iam_policy_document.assume_role.json --- modules/iam-group-with-assumable-roles-policy/variables.tf @@ -15,6 +15,12 @@ variable "assumable_roles" { default = [] } +variable "assumable_roles_policy_name_suffix" { + description = "Append this name to the policy name that will be created for assuming the given roles (default: null -- the policy name will be group name)" + type = string + default = "" +} + variable "group_users" { description = "List of IAM users to have in an IAM group which can assume the role" type = list(string) --- wrappers/iam-group-with-assumable-roles-policy/main.tf @@ -3,9 +3,10 @@ module "wrapper" { for_each = var.... **Inspecting variable syntax**

Ive spotted an error in Choice D where an extra name) has been inserted erroneously at 'default = []' in variables.tf. It seems like a stray leftover that could cause a syntax issue. 

Choices A and C look identical because they display the same code modifications. Now I need to determine the differences in context and examples. Review of A shows that the `variables.tf` is correctly assigning a default value to `assumable_roles_policy_name_suffix`.**Analyzing README and choices**

I've noticed a mismatch in the README where the default shows "" while the description states it's default: nullit's not critical, but worth noting. 

The wrappers added mapping to pass the argument 'assumable_roles_policy_name_suffix = try(..., "")', which looks good, and it seems both choices A and C provide the same correct implementation. Im curious why there are two identical choices, though. 

Choosing between A and C is a bit tricky, as I need to ensure nothing is missing. It's crucial to verify if any policy attachment resources need updating. The implementation looks solid so far!**Verifying code choices**

In examining choice A, I saw that the example file has consistent spaces aligning assignments, and no trailing issues. I need to ensure the code is syntactically valid. The `variables.tf` has a variable block without any extra stray characters, which is good. 

I did spot that the README states the default for 'assumable_roles_policy_name_suffix' as "" while describing it as nullit's a minor detail. Choice B is missing the for_each, and choice D includes a stray 'name)', leading to a syntax error. Between A and C, theyre identical, so Ill go with A!

Task Description:
## Description
This PR fixes default IAM permissions for user group created by `iam-group-with-policies` module, extending it to allow users set and read own access keys description when creating them via AWS Console.

## Motivation and Context
The issue with missing permissions was already addressed before by PR #287 , but the lines looks like were just lost after some major changes.

## Breaking Changes
None.

## How Has This Been Tested?
By applying the change to existing policies and checking AWS console.


---

Choice A:
modules/iam-group-with-policies/policies.tf
@@ -53,7 +53,10 @@ data "aws_iam_policy_document" "iam_self_management" {
       "iam:DeleteAccessKey",
       "iam:ListAccessKeys",
       "iam:UpdateAccessKey",
-      "iam:GetAccessKeyLastUsed"
+      "iam:GetAccessKeyLastUsed",
+      "iam:TagUser",
+      "iam:ListUserTags",
+      "iam:UntagUser",
     ]
 
     resources = [
---

-      "iam:GetAccessKeyLastUsed"
+      "iam:GetAccessKeyLastUsed",

+      "iam:UntagUser",

     resources = [

@@ -53,7 +53,10 @@ data "aws_iam_policy_document" "iam_self_management" {
